content:
UK

UK PM May spoke to US President Trump and was clear a trade deal can be done. PM May also said that she has discussed future trade deals with countries such as Japan, Canada, Chile and Australia, while she added that the international trade system is under significant strain. (Newswires)

UK's Brexit Minister Barclay said could see no deal or no Brexit if UK PM May’s deal is voted down. (Newswires)

PolhomeEditor political editor noted that a Labour source commented that the 52-page Brexit legal advice document falls far short of what Parliament demanded and is not the full legal advice, while a Parliamentary speaker said there is an arguable case that the UK government is committed to contempt to parliament over a Brexit advice. In related news, UK Speaker of the House Bercow said he will take rapid decision on letter from UK opposition parties alleging contempt over lack of legal advice from the government over Brexit. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 53.1 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.1). (Newswires)


EU

Eurogroup said it plans to back the EU's Commission view on Italy's budget and that fiscal expansion in Italy is “particularly worrying”. Elsewhere, there were comments from Italian PM Conte that he is not working on a 2019 budget which has a deficit below 2%, while Italy Deputy PM Salvini said the basics of the Italian budget will not change and that they have no interest in collision with the EU commission. (Newswires/ANSA)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said policy will remain expansive even after QE ends, while he added they should not delay normalisation unnecessarily and that the next step depends on data. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Nov) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.5). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Russia and Saudi Arabia are said to differ on how to share oil cuts as Saudi wants an equal distribution of cuts, while Russia wants to cut by a maximum of 150k BPD. In separate news, Saudi oil minister Al Falih said he has spoken to Algerian oil minister as part of effort to stabilise oil market. (Newswires)

OPEC key-members are reportedly returning to determine a new output deal, despite Qatar's withdrawal from the group. (Platts)
 

US

US Congress is planning to delay the government shutdown and border wall fight till the Friday before Christmas, while it was also reported that Congressional leaders unveiled a stop gap bill to extend funding for 2 weeks to avoid a partial government shutdown on Friday. Furthermore, Democrats signalled they would accept two-week stopgap spending bill and would line up budget fight for Christmas week. (Newswires/Politico)

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) said neutral rate is not very precise but is a useful concept and that they currently at the bottom of neutral rate range. Quarles also commented that the Fed should operate with data dependency and not react to 'every wavering' or change course without significant cause. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said he is focused on not being pre-determined about the future path of rates, while he added he is paying attention to slowdown in global growth and expects US growth to slow next year. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said he is cautiously optimistic about China-US deal and that they are pretty close to deal on IP, while he also stated that China is committed to lifting tariffs and non-tariff barriers immediately including the 40% auto tariffs and retaliatory tariffs on US commodities. Furthermore, Kudlow said there are scheduled meetings with German automakers this week which is is not about setting car tariffs and is meant to encourage them to produce engines in the US. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said this is the first time US has got an agreement that China will make progress in key areas and hopeful it can be turned into a real agreement. However, Mnuchin added that tariffs will be implemented if agreement doesn’t come, while he also commented that the US is to make sure China is not manipulating its currency. Elsewhere, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said Fed Chair Powell has a difficult job because he was left with a large balance sheet which he is trying to right-size, while he added that rates were low and Powell was left with hard work of normalising rates. (Newswires)

White House Trade Advisor Navarro said US Trade Representative Lightizer will be in charge of negotiations with China over the next 90 days. (NPR)

US ISM Manufacturing PMI Nov 59.3 vs. Exp. 57.6 (Prev. 57.7). (Newswires)
US ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid Nov 60.7 vs. Exp. 70.0 (Prev. 71.6)
US Construction Spending MM Oct -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Rev. -0.1%)


MARKET RECAP

Chipmakers including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Micron (MU), NVIDIA (NVDA), Broadcom (AVGO), Intel (INTC) all opened higher on the back of positive US/China trade developments. Casino names Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) outperformed after strong sales data for November in the Macau region. A rebound in crude prices projected oil names higher (COP, PXD, EOG, NBL, APC). FAANG (FB, AAPL, AMZN, NFLX, GOOGL) and industrials (CAT, BA, DE) also benefitted from the China/US trade developments with the two groups surging on the open. Discovery (DISCA) underperformed on it announcing a fall in its ad revenue forecasting. Video game developers Activision (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) continued their selloff from last week; with BoAML defending TTWO saying it had been oversold. Verizon (VZ) opened lower following a downgrade at JPMorgan. General Motors (GM) CEO Mary Barra will meet with senators Wednesday to talk about recent plant closings. Fox (FOXA) dropped in later trading after Brazilian regulators said the acquisition by Disney (DIS) was a cause for concern. SPX +1.09% at 2790, NDX +1.63% at 7062, DJI +1.13% at 25826.

US Treasuries were offered at the beginning of the week, with risk rallying on a 'trade ceasefire' between US/China. That helped equities gap open, and yields rise. However, the risk moves were faded as the session wore on, with analysts noting that the delay in implementing tariff hikes (or implementing fresh rounds of tariffs) was not a permanent solution; indeed, some had observed the differences between the official US and Chinese statements, where the US offered more colour (though not detail). Nevertheless, yields on 2s were still higher at settlement while the rest of the curve came in, forcing some of the major curves to narrow. Of particular note was the inversion of the 3s5s curve, while 2s30s was around 0.5bps at settle. Looking to the rest of the week, catalysts include the ongoing trade rhetoric, and payrolls at the end of the week; with the Fed reiterating a data-dependent approach to policy, the employment situation report may regain some of the significance it held at the height of the crisis. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 4+ ticks higher at 119-22.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 3 December: Trade ceasefire
content:

US MARKET WRAP – 3 December: Trade ceasefire

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, treasuries mixed, dollar down, crude up.

* REAR-VIEW: UK government publishes Brexit legal advice, optimism over US-China trade continues post-G20, Italian government eyes 1.9%-2.0% budget plan, ISM Mfg PMI strong, Construction Spending dips.

* AHEAD: RBA Interest Rate Decision, House of Commons Brexit deal debate begins, UK Construction PMI, BoE’s Carney, Broadbent, Vlieghe to speak, Fed’s Williams to speak, ECB’s De Guindos to speak, APIs weekly inventories.

 

* TRADE: Optimism continued after US President Trump and Chinese President Xi announced a truce at the G20 where the US agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days, paving the way for more trade discussions. On Monday, Trump announced that relations with China have taken a step forward while Treasury Secretary Mnuchin expressed hope that a real agreement will be reached given that China has showed willingness to make progress in key areas for the first time; he warned however that tariffs will be implemented warning that if an agreement doesn’t come. Similarly, White House Economic Advisor Kudlow stated that there was "good chemistry" between Trump and Xi at their meeting and therefore he is cautiously optimistic over a deal; he highlighted they are pretty close to a deal on IPs and claimed that China is committed to lifting tariffs, non-tariff barriers immediately, including the 40% auto tariffs and retaliatory tariffs on US commodities. He also announced that USTR Lighthizer will enforce a 90-day timetable during negotiations, beginning January 1st.

*  ITALY: Finance Minister Tria announced on Monday that Italy are negotiating with the European Commission to lower the 2019 deficit/GDP target to between 1.9%-2.0%; in later comments however, PM Conte stated he is not working on a budget below 2% while Deputy PM Salvini stressed that the EU cannot ask for a 1.9% and reiterated the basics will not change. European Commission Vice President Dombrovskis urged once again for substantial corrections are needed in the Italian budget, adding that it is up to Italy now to come up with adjustments and is not calling for concrete steps taken by Italy now.

* BREXIT: The UK government has published a 43-page summary of the Brexit legal advice which has raised fear among MPs that the UK could remain stuck in the EU indefinitely since it makes clear the backstop will continue until both the UK and EU can agree other customs arrangements.  Some have suggested that the document fell short of what the Commons requested last month and argued that the full legal advice contains warnings on the backstop that have not been outlined in this document, making it impossible for the UK to escape from the backstop unilaterally.

* FED: Fed Vice Chair Clarida said the US baseline outlook is very solid and noted that the Fed dot projections of interest rates are "not going anywhere". Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-Voter) continues to make the case to hold off on rate hikes, warning that the Fed could inadvertently push the economy into recession if it continues boosting borrowing costs. Fed's Kaplan (Dove, Non-Voter) urged the Fed to be “very patient” as it considers further rate evidence of slower inflation and softening global growth hikes, given the impact of past rises. Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) reiterated the Fed's data dependency approach and noted that the neutral rate is not very precise but is a useful concept, currently at the bottom of neutral rate range. He added the performance of the economy would indicate the Fed is doing a good job. Fed's Brainard (Voter, Neutral) stated that the US economy is at or beyond full employment and inflation is around target.

* US ISM MANUFACTURING PMI rose to 59.3 from 57.7 in November, beating expectations of 57.6. New orders came in at a strong 62.1 supported by strong domestic orders; employment also posted gains rising to 58.4 from 56.8, above the 56.5 consensus. On the flip side, prices paid moderated to 60.7 from 71.6 and missed expectations at 70.0; Scotiabank argues the weakness in this print may reflect the recent slump in oil prices. Overall, Scotiabank they are that the “domestic economy’s strengths outweigh anything of concern in terms of the external side of the US picture” and note that today’s reading “outperformed what regional surveys like the Philly and Richmond metrics”.

* CONSTRUCTION SPENDING fell by 0.1% in October, missing expectations of a 0.4% rise; the prior was also revised down to -0.1% with the headline declining for the 3rd consecutive month. The weakness was led by residentials who were down 0.5% while non-residential rose mildly by 0.1%; also home building remains “sluggish” as affordability issues continue to play a role. Nonetheless, Wells Fargo sates that “spending remains up 4.9% year-over-year”.

SPX +1.09% at 2790, NDX +1.63% at 7062, DJI +1.13% at 25826. SECTORS: Energy +2.28%, Materials +1.74%, Industrials +1.17%, Cons Discretionary +2.21%, Cons Staples -0.09%, Healthcare +0.44%, Financials +0.47%, Tech +2.11%, Telecoms +0.07%, Utilities +0.88%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Chipmakers including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Micron (MU), NVIDIA (NVDA), Broadcom (AVGO), Intel (INTC) all opened higher on the back of positive US/China trade developments. Casino names Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) outperformed after strong sales data for November in the Macau region. A rebound in crude prices projected oil names higher (COP, PXD, EOG, NBL, APC). FAANG (FB, AAPL, AMZN, NFLX, GOOGL) and industrials (CAT, BA, DE) also benefitted from the China/US trade developments with the two groups surging on the open. Discovery (DISCA) underperformed on it announcing a fall in its ad revenue forecasting. Video game developers Activision (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) continued their selloff from last week; with BoAML defending TTWO saying it had been oversold. Verizon (VZ) opened lower following a downgrade at JPMorgan. General Motors (GM) CEO Mary Barra will meet with senators Wednesday to talk about recent plant closings. Fox (FOXA) dropped in later trading after Brazilian regulators said the acquisition by Disney (DIS) was a cause for concern.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 2.02 HIGHER AT USD 52.95/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 2.23 HIGHER AT USD 61.69/BBL. The crude is up, though off highs, bouncing on Monday due to a combination of the positive outcome on the Trump/Xi ‘trade ceasefire’ reached at the G20, that helps support global growth and consequentially, oil demand; it also helped support risk sentiment, which was positive for crude. Additionally, at the G20, Russia said it will continue to be part of the OPEC+ pact to cut crude output into 2019. Analysts have noted that no specific cut level was touted, and allocations of cuts was also not mentioned. Ahead of the OPEC meeting on 6-7 December, the consensus expects a cut of between 1.0mln BPD and 1.4mln BPD. The complex has also been supported by news that Alberta temporarily cutting 325k BPD of oil sands production in January, until excess crude in storage is drawn down. The latest newswire surveys sees estimates of OPEC crude production slightly moderating in November, with the 350k BPD rise in Saudi production offsetting the 500k BPD fall in Iranian output.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 4+ TICKS HIGHER AT 119-22. US Treasuries were offered at the beginning of the week, with risk rallying on a 'trade ceasefire' between US/China. That helped equities gap open, and yields rise. However, the risk moves were faded as the session wore on, with analysts noting that the delay in implementing tariff hikes (or implementing fresh rounds of tariffs) was not a permanent solution; indeed, some had observed the differences between the official US and Chinese statements, where the US offered more colour (though not detail). Nevertheless, yields on 2s were still higher at settlement while the rest of the curve came in, forcing some of the major curves to narrow. Of particular note was the inversion of the 3s5s curve, while 2s30s was around 0.5bps at settle. Looking to the rest of the week, catalysts include the ongoing trade rhetoric, and payrolls at the end of the week; with the Fed reiterating a data-dependent approach to policy, the employment situation report may regain some of the significance it held at the height of the crisis.

* AUD, CAD, NZD: All just off best levels, but still markedly outperforming and holding healthy gains vs their US counterpart in wake of the accord between the US and China to hold off from further reciprocal import taxes for 3 months and redouble efforts to reach a formal trade agreement. Moreover, President Trump declares that big strides were made between the 2 nations after his meeting with China’s Xi and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin underlined this statement by noting a first in terms of receiving assurances from Beijing that it will change policies in key areas. Aud/Usd derived most from the positive developments and bullish if not quite euphoric post-G20 mood to scale new multi-month peaks just shy of 0.7400 before losing a bit of momentum ahead of the big figure where 1+ bn option expiries rolled off at the NY cut, and with the 200 DMA at 0.7418 also keeping buyers at bay. Meanwhile, the Loonie got an additional boost from a sharp rebound in crude, partly due to Canada’s decision to cut oil production in Alberta, but was still dogged by trade issues of its own with the US and retreated ahead of 1.3150, and the Kiwi was capped around 0.6940 after weaker than expected NZ terms of trade overnight.

* EUR, CHF, JPY, GBP: Ending Monday’s EU session narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency managing to stay above 1.1300 amidst reports that the Italian Government and EU are getting closer towards reaching a compromise on the 2019 deficit as the coalition is reportedly looking to cut the shortfall to 2% after yet another budget meeting today. Earlier Eur/Usd failed to test 1.1400 where more heavy offers are said to be sitting, and the headline pair also had decent option expiries in sight between 1.1380-90 (circa 1.3 bn). Mixed fortunes for the safe-havens, with the Franc back above parity and perhaps bolstered independently by firmer Swiss retail sales and above forecast manufacturing PMI, but the Jpy weaker for choice in the significantly improved risk environment and pivoting 113.50. The Pound endured a rocky ride with Cable up through 1.2800 stops at one stage to a high around 1.2825, but Brexit fears never far from the surface and pulling prices back through the round number (that also coincided with the 10 DMA), then the recent ‘Raab’ low (1.2725) to 1.2700 before the rot stopped – note, UK PM May to speak shortly and the Cox legal presentation was roundly jeered.

* EM: Widespread gains vs the Usd, that struggled to regain composure overall (DXY back briefly over 97.000, but only just), with the exception of the recently outperforming Turkish Lira that hit resistance around 5.1500 again and could not benefit from a decline in CPI given the aforementioned pronounced rebound in crude prices – Usd/Try now back up near 5.2850.

subject: UBS Weekly FX Flows: USD sold for fourth week
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD registered a second week of outflows as private clients were the only client group to buy the pair. Hedge funds led selling interest while corporates notched a seventh straight week of outflows.
  • USDJPY, EURJPY: USDJPY experienced a third week of outflows as private clients and hedge funds sold the pair while corporates and asset managers exhibited muted flows. JPY saw inflows vs. EUR, supported by a third week of hedge fund buying while asset managers and corporates registered marginal selling.
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD recorded strong buying interest, led by asset manager and hedge fund inflows while corporate and private clients demonstrated limited directionality. EURGBP was net bought as asset manager inflows outweighed hedge fund outflows.
  • EURCHF, USDCHF: EURCHF buying extended to a seventh week as asset managers and corporate clients registered buying interest. USDCHF saw outflows as all clients sold the pair with asset managers and corporates leading the way.
  • AUDUSD, NZDUSD, and USDCAD: AUDUSD registered marginal inflows as hedge fund buying just offset selling by asset managers and private clients. NZDUSD was bought for a fifth straight week, led by asset manager and hedge fund inflows. USDCAD flows were more or less flat as asset manager selling was offset by buying from all other client groups.
  • EURSEK, EURNOK, USDSEK, and USDNOK: SEK was bought vs EUR for a sixth week despite heavy corporate selling as hedge funds continued to bolster SEK inflows. EURNOK saw inflows, led primarily by hedge fund buying interest. USDSEK was sold amid asset manager and hedge fund outflows. USDNOK was net bought, led by hedge fund and asset manager inflows as other client flows were muted.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: non-US Dollars revel in G20 tariff ‘time out’
content:
AUD/CAD/NZD

All just off best levels, but still markedly outperforming and holding healthy gains vs their US counterpart in wake of the accord between the US and China to hold off from further reciprocal import taxes for 3 months and redouble efforts to reach a formal trade agreement. Moreover, President Trump declares that big strides were made between the 2 nations after his meeting with China’s Xi and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin underlined this statement by noting a first in terms of receiving assurances from Beijing that it will change policies in key areas. Aud/Usd derived most from the positive developments and bullish if not quite euphoric post-G20 mood to scale new multi-month peaks just shy of 0.7400 before losing a bit of momentum ahead of the big figure where 1+ bn option expiries rolled off at the NY cut, and with the 200 DMA at 0.7418 also keeping buyers at bay. Meanwhile, the Loonie got an additional boost from a sharp rebound in crude, partly due to Canada’s decision to cut oil production in Alberta, but was still dogged by trade issues of its own with the US and retreated ahead of 1.3150, and the Kiwi was capped around 0.6940 after weaker than expected NZ terms of trade overnight.

EUR/CHF/JPY/GBP

Ending Monday’s EU session narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency managing to stay above 1.1300 amidst reports that the Italian Government and EU are getting closer towards reaching a compromise on the 2019 deficit as the coalition is reportedly looking to cut the shortfall to 2% after yet another budget meeting today. Earlier Eur/Usd failed to test 1.1400 where more heavy offers are said to be sitting, and the headline pair also had decent option expiries in sight between 1.1380-90 (circa 1.3 bn). Mixed fortunes for the safe-havens, with the Franc back above parity and perhaps bolstered independently by firmer Swiss retail sales and above forecast manufacturing PMI, but the Jpy weaker for choice in the significantly improved risk environment and pivoting 113.50. The Pound endured a rocky ride with Cable up through 1.2800 stops at one stage to a high around 1.2825, but Brexit fears never far from the surface and pulling prices back through the round number (that also coincided with the 10 DMA), then the recent ‘Raab’ low (1.2725) to 1.2700 before the rot stopped – note, UK PM May to speak shortly and the Cox legal presentation was roundly jeered.

EM

Widespread gains vs the Usd, that struggled to regain composure overall (DXY back briefly over 97.000, but only just), with the exception of the recently outperforming Turkish Lira that hit resistance around 5.1500 again, and could not benefit from a decline in CPI given the aforementioned pronounced rebound in crude prices – Usd/Try now back up near 5.2850.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days
  • Russia President Putin spoke with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince in which they agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, although haven’t decided on the precise volume of production cuts
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Markit Manufacturing PMIs, Fed’s Quarles, Williams, Brainard, Kaplan, BoE’s Haldane Speaking

TRADE

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days to allow for discussions, while China agreed to buy a "very substantial" amount of agricultural, industrial and energy products from the US. Furthermore, there were reports that the G20 draft statement agreed that the current global trading system has flaws and is in need of reform. (Newswires/BBC)

US President Trump tweeted that China has agreed to reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the US which are currently at 40%. (Twitter)

Goldman Sachs said the actual amount of concrete progress at the Trump-Xi meeting seems quite limited as expected, while it added that there is just over 50% probability that discussions will fail and that the tariff increase to 25% will still happen in March or later. (Newswires)

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board with global risk appetite boosted following the US-China trade truce at the G20. News of the tariff ceasefire spurred a rally in US equity futures in which the Emini S&P and DJIA futures reclaimed the 2800 and 26000 levels respectively, with the blue-chip index up nearly 500 points. ASX 200 (+1.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) advanced with Australia led by commodity-related sectors as energy benefitted from the positive trade developments and Russia-Saudi agreement to extend the OPEC+ accord, while the JPY-risk dynamic was very much in play for Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) outperformed on the easing of trade tensions, with sentiment also supported by better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI and after the CFFEX relaxed domestic stock index futures trading conditions. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially saw a bout of weakness at the open amid the heightened risk appetite, although prices later recovered amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 800bln of JGBs with maturities of up to 5yrs.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9431 (Prev. 6.9357)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 50.2 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 50.1). (Newswires)

China Financial Futures Exchange CFFEX relaxed restrictions on domestic stock index futures trading with reports noting that some margin requirements and commissions are to be lowered. (Xinhua)

China's foreign ministry says US and China's Presidents have instructed their economic teams to work towards removing all tariffs. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li says the downward pressure on the economy is increasing. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May was reportedly under renewed pressure as the DUP threatened to abandon support for her in a confidence vote if she failed to get her Brexit deal approved in Parliament. (Times)

UK PM May's chief Brexit adviser Oliver Robbins secretly warned her the PM that customs backstop is a "bad outcome" for the UK which will see regulatory checks in the Irish Sea and put security co-operation at risk, according to the Telegraph. (Telegraph)

UK Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Gove, has told Conservative rebels that there was a “real risk” of a second Brexit referendum if they don’t back PM May’s deal with Brussels. (Times)

UK Shadow Brexit Secretary Starmer said that Labour would almost certainly seek a vote of no confidence if UK PM May loses the key Commons vote on her Brexit deal on December 11th. (The Guardian)

UK trade body EEF raised 2018 manufacturing production growth forecast to 1.1% from 0.9% but cut 2019 forecast to 0.3% from 0.5%. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte stated they are examining several options for a budget deal with the EU in which a solution could be made within days. (Newswires) Later it was reported, that Italian PM Conte is reportedly preparing for a deficit of 1.9%-2.0%, while Italian Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio are said to be ready to accept new target, according to Messaggero.  Italy's Deputy PM Salvini says that the EU cannot ask for a 1.9% target (Messaggero/Newswires)

European Commission Vice President Dombrovskis says substantial corrections are needed in the Italian budget. (Newswires)

German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI Final (Nov) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.6 (Prev. 51.6)

French Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Nov) 50.8 vs. Exp. 50.7 (Prev. 50.7)

Italian Markit/ADACI Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 48.6 vs. Exp. 48.9 (Prev. 49.2)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 53.1 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.1)

EU Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Nov) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.5 (Prev. 51.5)

 

ECB

ECB are to adopt a new capital key on January 1st, 2019.

- Bank of Italy's Capital Key to 11.8023% (vs. Prev. 12.3108%

- Bundesbank 18.3670% (vs. Prev. 17.9973%)

- Five-yearly adjustment based on population and GDP data from European Commission

- 16 national central banks to have higher share, 12 lower share

- No change in system of rotating voting rights

Link: https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2018/html/ecb.pr181203.en.html

 

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon and US President Trump agreed to revive momentum regarding negotiations for North Korea denuclearization. In related news, South Korean President Moon said a visit by North Korean Leader Kim to Seoul is still open and possible this year, while US President Trump is said to be targeting a summit with North Korean leader early 2019. (Newswires/Nikkei)

 

FX

DXY, CNY, JPY – An optimistic end to the G20 summit with Trump and Xi agreeing on a 90-day tariffs ceasefire until a trade deal can be negotiated (with sticking points such as IP remaining). As such DXY fell to lows of 96.710 vs. last week’s low of 96.622, though the index is nursing losses in an attempt to take another jab at 97.000. USD/CNY fell below the key 6.90 level despite a higher USD/CNY fix by the PBOC overnight, while JPY unwound some risk premium with USD/JPY stopping just shy of 114.00, but the headline pair supported just ahead of a downside tech-level (Tenken at 113.34).

AUD, NZD, CAD – Major high-beta beneficiaries in the aftermath of the G20, with AUD/USD within striking distance of 0.7400 (where 1.365bln in option expiries lie) ahead of its 200DMA at 0.7418, while the Kiwi holds above 0.6900, marginally hampered by weaker than expected Q3 terms of trade and softer export volumes. Meanwhile, CAD also takes advantage of the rising oil prices after Russia and KSA extended their OPEC+ pact, on top of the tactical 325k BPD production cut at Canada’s Alberta refinery. USD/CAD currently sub-1.3200 but off post-G20 lows of 1.3160.

SEK, NOK – An improvement in the manufacturing PMI has provided the Swedish Crown with some extra fuel to break through 10.2500 vs. the EUR. Nordea notes that all sub-indices rose (ex-employment) while also adding that the release is in line with NIER’s improved sentiment. Meanwhile, NOK also deriving gains from the oil complex with EUR/NOK giving up the 9.7000 handle to sit just above 9.6800. However, NOK gains are capped by pre-positioning for the next Norges Bank F-loan payment on December 6th.

GBP, EUR - Little reaction in the pound and the single currency following mixed manufacturing PMIs with Cable back down below 1.2750 (after having breached its 10DMA at 1.2800 where stops were reportedly tripped) and through the Raab-low at 1.2724 to test bids ahead of 1.2700, while EUR/USD couldn’t sustain gains to 1.1400 before retreating through 1.1350 and towards 1.1300. Note, the single currency was supported earlier on Italian press reports that PM Conte is said to be preparing for a deficit/GDP target in the range of 1.9%-2.0%, with the Deputy PMs apparently ready to accept the new target but has eased back in wake of the ECB’s announcement of Capital Key changes, including a perhaps surprisingly lower Italian ratio. In terms of option expiries, EUR/USD sees 1.32bln around 1.1380-90 ahead of reported offers at 1.1400.

EM – TRY back in focus with softer than expected Turkish CPI helping the Lira retest recent highs around 5.1500 vs. the buck at one stage, but unable to breach resistance as the USD stage a broad comeback.

 

FIXED INCOME

Core EU bonds are still in negative territory as the US-China trade truce has resulted in the unwinding of pre-G20 premiums in the fixed income scope. Gilts derived little inspiration from a marked beat on the UK manufacturing PMI and languish around 122.50 vs. 122.69 at best, with a contract high of 123.22 eyed should any upside be struck by BoE’s Haldane later in the day. Bunds and BTPs also ignored the EZ readings, with the latter instead paying heed to a possible 2.0% debt/GDP ratio and hanging around highs of 125.24 (+55 ticks) with a fib level of 125.34 still being targeted to the upside. Bunds also remain around session highs at 161.40 (-21 ticks) with the German 10 year keeping aforementioned resistance at 161.41-44 prior to a psychological level of 161.50 ahead of Friday’s close of 161.54 and peak of 161.58 in mind.

US 10 year yields have maintained gains above 3.0% mark, albeit only by a few bp, with the benchmark future trading with losses of 6 ticks ahead of an action packed week, which kicks off with the dovish Clarida in today's session ahead of multiple speeches from Fed Chair Powell and supply from the US.

 

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +1.8%) trade with firm gains as markets react to the fallout of the G20 summit which saw US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agree to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days to allow for trade discussions between the two nations. In terms of sector specifics, mining names have been the main beneficiary from the trade optimism thus far with price action in metals markets giving a lift to Antofagasta (+8.0%), Arcelormittal (+6.6%), Anglo American (+6.3%), Glenore (+6.5%) and many more. Elsewhere, luxury names are also seeing some reprieve from the US-China developments with the sector previously hampered by tensions between the two nations; as such, Swatch (+6.1%), Kering (+5.5%), LVMH (+4.3%) and Burberry (+3.3%) all trade with firm gains. Auto names are also seen higher amid the spillover from US President Trump tweeting that China has agreed to reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the US which are currently at 40%; BMW (+6.1%), Daimler (+6.2%), Volkswagen (+3.9%). Finally, tech names have also been supported by the weekend’s developments with tech a key focus for negotiations, subsequently, STMicroelectronics (+7.3%), Infineon (+5.8%) and Wirecard (+4.4%) are also near the top of the Stoxx 600 leaderboard.

 

COMMODITIES 

WTI (+4.1%) and Brent (+3.9%) are both stronger following the positive US-China trade news and reports that Russia and Saudi Arabia are agreeing to extend the OPEC+ agreement; although no production cut figure has been announced so far. Additionally, Qatar, which produces approximately 600,000 BPD of oil, has announced that they are withdrawing from OPEC as of January with this being in-line with their long-term plan. Separately, Canada’s Alberta province is to reportedly mandate a 9% oil output reduction, which amounts to 325,000 BPD, in order to ease a supply glut with this to come into effect from January.

 Gold (+0.7%) is firmer, albeit off of a 3-week high of USD 1232.30/oz reached earlier in the session; after gaining support from the dollar being weighed on by positive US-China trade news from the G20 summit. Steel and copper prices have also benefited from the positive trade news, with Chinese rebar steel increasing by its 7% exchange-set trading; with copper’s London benchmark prices nearing a two-month high.

Russia President Putin spoke with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince in which they agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, although haven’t decided on the precise volume of production cuts. (Newswires)

Canada's Alberta mandates 325k bpd or 9% output reduction in oil to ease supply glut effective January. (Newswires)


OPEC Economic Panel recommended an output cut from October levels according to reports on Friday, while it was also noted that a 1.3mln bpd cut seen as efficient to balance the market. (WSJ)

Fixed Income: not much reaction to EU manufacturing PMIs
content: Not even a sizeable UK headline beat sparked much reaction in core bonds as Gilts sit just a few ticks off a fresh Liffe peak of 122.64, flat from their previous settlement vs 39 ticks below at one stage, with the November survey revealing some far less encouraging sub-components, like export orders that fell for the second consecutive month. Meanwhile, mixed Eurozone results were also largely ignored, or at least shrugged off even though Italy’s contraction intensified, with Bunds and BTPs also holding near best levels. Technically, the 10 year German benchmark has resistance up at 161.41-44 ahead of Friday’s close and intraday peak at 161.54 and 161.58 respectively, while support remains around 161.00. Elsewhere, US Treasuries have inched up from overnight session lows and the curve is not quite as steep ahead of a relatively busy Monday agenda including data, several Fed speakers and the first slug of this week’s hefty supply.

subject: Goldman Sachs on Alberta/OPEC
content:
• GS estimate the Alberta production cut will reduce output by 200k bpd Y/Y relative to their previous expectations
  • Expect OPEC to follow suit with a cut on Thursday in Vienna
  • Despite interventions from Trump, recent negative headlines about impact of prices on shale CAPEX and a dovish Fed will allow a cut to occur
  • Believe a 1.3mln bpd cut is needed to bring stocks back to their 5 year average level
  • Production cut should extend the really see since Sunday and bring Brent prices back to the mid-USD 60/bbl level.
  • Brent forward curve is only currently pricing in a 700k bpd cut.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures down, but not out
content: A decent recovery in Gilts, and arguably even more impressive or at least pronounced along the Short Sterling strip as the former pares losses from an early 122.25 Liffe low to 122.55 (-9 ticks on the day) alongside Bunds that have decoupled somewhat from BTPs and the ongoing advance in EU cash bourses. Indeed, the 10 year German debt futures recently rebounded to 161.34 (-20 ticks vs -53 ticks off the Eurex open) even though its Italian counterpart has inched a tad further towards near term resistance and a Fib at 125.34, with a fresh peak of 125.24. Back to Liffe, and 3 month contracts are now just 0.5 tick either side of unchanged vs as much as 4 ticks adrift earlier, as attention switches from broader risk themes to the manufacturing PMI.

Bunds: hanging on to 161.00 handle, for now at least
content: The 10 year German benchmark survived a very early test of bids/support just ahead of 161.00 after a gap down to 161.01 from last Friday’s 161.54 close, but the subsequent bounce to 161.18 was fragile and fleeting as core bonds concede ground to the post-G20 revival in risk sentiment. Moreover, Bunds have a sharp rebound in BTPs to contend with as the 10 year debt futures rallies over 125.00 to 125.10 and close to a key Fib at 125.34 that several tech charts have been flagging on the back of latest reports suggesting Italian PM Conte is looking at a 2% or even 1.9% 2019 deficit, and pertinently with the approval of Deputies Salvini and Di Maio. Confirmation after another meeting between the top coalition Government officials in Rome later today could well see Italian assets trade higher, while a bullish open for EU equities may see 161.00 breached before some potential props in the form of Eurozone manufacturing PMIs that look set to be weak.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Astrazeneca (AZN LN) – The Co’s agreement with Grunenthal for the rights to Nexium in Europe and Vimovo worldwide have completed. Co has received USD 700mln for Nexium and USD 115mln for Vimovo. (Newswires)

RPC (RPC LN) – The Co and Bain Capital have mutually agreed to terminate discussions. Discussions on a possible offer remain ongoing with Apollo Global Management. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board with global risk appetite boosted following the US-China trade truce at the G20. News of the tariff ceasefire spurred a rally in US equity futures in which the Emini S&P and DJIA futures reclaimed the 2800 and 26000 levels respectively, with the blue-chip index up nearly 500 points. ASX 200 (+1.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) advanced with Australia led by commodity-related sectors as energy benefitted from the positive trade developments and Russia-Saudi agreement to extend the OPEC+ accord, while the JPY-risk dynamic was very much in play for Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) outperformed on the easing of trade tensions, with sentiment also supported by better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI and after the CFFEX relaxed domestic stock index futures trading conditions.

FTSE

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days
  • Russia President Putin spoke with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince in which they agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, although haven’t decided on the precise volume of production cuts
  • Italian PM Conte is reportedly preparing for a deficit of 1.9%-2.0%, while Italian Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio are said to be ready to accept new target
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EU, UK, US Markit Manufacturing PMIs, Fed’s Quarles, Williams, Brainard, Kaplan, BoE’s Haldane Speaking

TRADE

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods to 25% for 90 days to allow for discussions, while China agreed to buy a "very substantial" amount of agricultural, industrial and energy products from the US. Furthermore, there were reports that the G20 draft statement agreed that the current global trading system has flaws and is in need of reform. (Newswires/BBC)

US President Trump tweeted that China has agreed to reduce and remove tariffs on cars coming into China from the US which are currently at 40%. (Twitter)

Goldman Sachs said the actual amount of concrete progress at the Trump-Xi meeting seems quite limited as expected, while it added that there is just over 50% probability that discussions will fail and that the tariff increase to 25% will still happen in March or later. (Newswires)


ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board with global risk appetite boosted following the US-China trade truce at the G20. News of the tariff ceasefire spurred a rally in US equity futures in which the Emini S&P and DJIA futures reclaimed the 2800 and 26000 levels respectively, with the blue-chip index up nearly 500 points. ASX 200 (+1.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) advanced with Australia led by commodity-related sectors as energy benefitted from the positive trade developments and Russia-Saudi agreement to extend the OPEC+ accord, while the JPY-risk dynamic was very much in play for Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) outperformed on the easing of trade tensions, with sentiment also supported by better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI and after the CFFEX relaxed domestic stock index futures trading conditions. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially saw a bout of weakness at the open amid the heightened risk appetite, although prices later recovered amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 800bln of JGBs with maturities of up to 5yrs.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9431 (Prev. 6.9357)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 50.2 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 50.1). (Newswires)

China Financial Futures Exchange CFFEX relaxed restrictions on domestic stock index futures trading with reports noting that some margin requirements and commissions arel be lowered. (Xinhua)


UK/EU

UK PM May was reportedly under renewed pressure as the DUP threatened to abandon support for her in a confidence vote if she failed to get her Brexit deal approved in Parliament. (Times)

UK PM May's chief Brexit adviser Oliver Robbins secretly warned her the PM that customs backstop is a "bad outcome" for the UK which will see regulatory checks in the Irish Sea and put security co-operation at risk, according to the Telegraph. (Telegraph)

UK Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Gove, has told Conservative rebels that there was a “real risk” of a second Brexit referendum if they don’t back PM May’s deal with Brussels. (Times)

UK Shadow Brexit Secretary Starmer said that Labour would almost certainly seek a vote of no confidence if UK PM May loses the key Commons vote on her Brexit deal on December 11th. (The Guardian)

UK trade body EEF raised 2018 manufacturing production growth forecast to 1.1% from 0.9% but cut 2019 forecast to 0.3% from 0.5%. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte stated they are examining several options for a budget deal with the EU in which a solution could be made within days. (Newswires) Later it was reported, that Italian PM Conte is reportedly preparing for a deficit of 1.9%-2.0%, while Italian Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio are said to be ready to accept new target, according to Messaggero. (Messaggero)

Swiss government said on Friday to adopt provisional ban on trading of Swiss shares on European stock exchanges amid row with EU over new treaty to take effect on January 1st 2019. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Ireland at 'A+/A-1'; Outlook Stable, while Fitch affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Portugal at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, USD was softer as the US-China trade truce spurred outflows from safe-haven currencies which also underpinned JPY-crosses and benefitted most of the greenback’s major counterparts. As such, EUR/USD strengthened with the pair also supported by hopes of a potential Italian budget solution within days, while gains in GBP/USD were moderate amid ongoing Brexit-related uncertainty with the DUP threatening to abandon support for PM May in a confidence vote if her Brexit deal fails in Parliament. Elsewhere, AUD, NZD and CAD appreciated due to their high-beta statuses and amid a surge in commodity prices in which WTI crude futures and several Chinese base metals rallied over 5%.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were higher across the board in which WTI crude futures stole the limelight as it gained over 5% in the aftermath of the G20 developments including the US-China trade truce and Russia-Saudi agreement to extend the OPEC+ accord. The oil rally was further exacerbated as Shanghai commodities trade got underway and amid reports Canada’s Alberta is to cut oil output by 9% due to a supply glut. Elsewhere, gold saw marginal gains with upside restricted amid lack of demand for safe-havens, while copper gapped higher amid outperformance in China and broad strength across Shanghai commodities trade.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (30/Nov): Oil up 2 rigs at 887, gas down 5 rigs at 189, total rigs down 3 at 1076. (Newswires)

Russia President Putin spoke with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince in which they agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, although haven’t decided on the precise volume of production cuts. (Newswires)

Canada's Alberta mandates 325k bpd or 9% output reduction in oil to ease supply glut effective January. (Newswires)


OPEC Economic Panel recommended an output cut from October levels according to reports on Friday, while it was also noted that a 1.3mln bpd cut seen as efficient to balance the market. (WSJ)


GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon and US President Trump agreed to revive momentum regarding negotiations for North Korea denuclearization. In related news, South Korean President Moon said a visit by North Korean Leader Kim to Seoul is still open and possible this year, while US President Trump is said to be targeting a summit with North Korean leader early 2019. (Newswires/Nikkei)

US

The Treasury complex seemed to have been detached from the broader themes (G20/trade/etc) on Friday and once again put in a lacklustre performance with a thin range, as traders refrained from making any major moves ahead of the outcome of the dinner between Trump/Xi, as well as on month-end. Fed’s Kashkari (dove, non-voter) also lent some support to the complex, though in reality, it was a rattling-off of his usual dovish views. Major curve spreads narrowed modestly by between 0.5bps to 2bps, though 10s30s were a touch wider. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 4 ticks higher at 119-17+.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: US-China tariff truce G20 sparks relief rally
content:
Asia equity markets are higher across the board with global risk appetite boosted following the US-China trade truce at the G20 in which US President Trump agreed to delay hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods for 90 days and China agreed to buy a "very substantial" amount of US products. News of the tariff ceasefire lifted US equity futures with the Emini S&P gaining around 1.5% to test 2800.00 and with DJIA futures higher by over 400 points to reclaim the 26000 level. As such, ASX 200 (+1.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) advanced with Australia led by commodity-related sectors as energy and metals benefit from the positive trade developments as well as news Russia and Saudi agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, while the JPY-risk dynamic is very much in play for Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+2.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.5%) outperform on the easing of trade tensions, with sentiment also supported by better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI and after the CFFEX relaxed domestic stock index futures trading conditions.

In FX markets, USD is softer as the US-China trade truce spurred outflows from safe-haven currencies which has underpinned JPY-crosses and benefitted most of the greenback’s major counterparts. EUR/USD trades firmer with the pair also supported by hopes of a potential Italian budget solution within days, while gains in GBP/USD are somewhat moderated amid ongoing Brexit-related uncertainty with the DUP threatening to abandon support for PM May in a confidence vote if her Brexit deal fails in Parliament. Elsewhere, AUD, NZD and CAD are lifted due to their high-beta statuses and amid a surge in energy prices with WTI crude futures higher by over 5% in the aftermath of the G20 developments and with Canada’s Alberta announcing to cut output by 9% amid a supply glut.

Finally, 10yr JGBs initially saw a bout of weakness at the open amid the heightened risk appetite, although prices have since recovered amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 800bln of JGBs with maturities of up to 5yrs.
